description: Master electrical circuits, power systems, electronics, and modern electrical technologies

chapters.title: Electrical Fundamentals
chapters.description: Core concepts of electricity, circuit analysis, and basic laws

lessons.title: Atomic Structure and Electricity
objectives: Understand the structure of atoms and electron behavior
Explain the concept of electrical charge
Differentiate between conductors, semiconductors, and insulators
Describe how current flows in materials

content.introduction: Electricity is fundamental to our modern world. To understand how electrical systems work, we must first explore the atomic structure of matter and how electrons behave.

sections.title: Atomic Structure
sections.content: Every atom consists of a nucleus containing protons (positively charged) and neutrons (neutral), surrounded by electrons (negatively charged) orbiting in energy shells.

sections.title: Electrical Charge
sections.content: The elementary charge of an electron is -1.6 × 10^-19 coulombs. When electrons move from one atom to another, we get electric current.

sections.title: Conductors vs Insulators
sections.content: Conductors have free electrons that can move easily (e.g., copper, aluminum). Insulators hold electrons tightly (e.g., rubber, plastic, glass).

formulas.description: Charge (Q) equals current (I) multiplied by time (t)
Number of electrons equals charge divided by elementary charge

problems.title: Calculate Electron Flow
problems.description: A current of 2 amperes flows through a wire for 10 seconds. Calculate the total charge transferred.
steps: Apply the formula: Q = I × t

lessons.title: Voltage, Current, and Resistance
objectives: Understand the relationship between these three quantities
Identify common components and their values

content.introduction: Voltage, current, and resistance are the three fundamental quantities in electrical circuits. Understanding their relationships is essential for circuit analysis.

sections.title: Voltage (Potential Difference)
sections.content: Voltage is the electrical pressure that pushes electrons through a conductor. It's measured in volts (V). Think of it as the 'pressure' in a water pipe system.

sections.title: Current
sections.content: Current is the flow of electrons through a conductor, measured in amperes (A). One ampere equals one coulomb of charge passing a point per second.

sections.title: Resistance
sections.content: Resistance opposes the flow of current, measured in ohms (Ω). Factors affecting resistance include material, length, cross-sectional area, and temperature.

formulas.description: Ohm's Law: Voltage equals current times resistance
Resistance of a conductor: resistivity × length ÷ cross-sectional area

problems.title: Basic Ohm's Law
problems.description: Calculate the current flowing through a 100Ω resistor when connected to a 12V source.

lessons.title: Ohm's Law and Power
objectives: Master Ohm's Law and its applications
Select appropriate wire gauges based on current

content.introduction: Ohm's Law is the foundation of all electrical calculations. Combined with power formulas, it allows us to analyze any DC circuit.

sections.title: The Ohm's Law Triangle
sections.content: Use the Ohm's Law triangle to remember relationships: V at top, I and R at bottom. Cover the unknown quantity to see the formula.

sections.title: Electrical Power
sections.content: Power is the rate of doing work, measured in watts (W). Higher power means more energy consumed per unit time.

sections.title: Power Formulas
sections.content: Power can be calculated using: P = VI, P = I²R, or P = V²/R. Choose based on known quantities.

problems.title: Power Calculation
problems.description: A 60W light bulb operates at 120V. Calculate the current drawn by the bulb.

problems.title: Energy Consumption
problems.description: A 1500W electric heater runs for 4 hours. Calculate the energy consumed in kilowatt-hours (kWh).
steps: Apply energy formula: E = P × t

lessons.title: Series Circuits
objectives: Analyze current flow in series circuits

content.introduction: Series circuits have components connected end-to-end, forming a single path for current flow. Understanding series circuits is essential for all circuit analysis.

sections.title: Series Circuit Characteristics
sections.content: In series circuits: current is the same through all components, total voltage divides across components, total resistance equals sum of individual resistances.

sections.title: Total Resistance
sections.content: R_total = R1 + R2 + R3 + ... + Rn. The more resistors in series, the higher the total resistance.

sections.title: Voltage Divider Rule
sections.content: The voltage across a resistor is proportional to its resistance: Vn = V_total × (Rn / R_total)

problems.title: Series Resistance
problems.description: Three resistors of 100Ω, 200Ω, and 300Ω are connected in series. Calculate the total resistance.
steps: Add all resistance values: R_total = R1 + R2 + R3

content.introduction: Parallel circuits provide multiple paths for current flow. This configuration is common in household wiring and electronic devices.

sections.title: Parallel Circuit Characteristics
sections.content: In parallel circuits: voltage is the same across all components, total current divides among branches, total resistance decreases as more branches are added.

sections.title: Total Resistance
sections.content: 1/R_total = 1/R1 + 1/R2 + 1/R3 + ... + 1/Rn. For two resistors: R_total = (R1 × R2) / (R1 + R2)

sections.title: Current Divider Rule
sections.content: Current through a branch is inversely proportional to its resistance: In = I_total × (R_total / Rn)

problems.title: Parallel Resistance
problems.description: Two 100Ω resistors are connected in parallel. Calculate the total resistance.
steps: Apply parallel formula: R_total = (R1 × R2) / (R1 + R2)

content.introduction: Most practical circuits combine series and parallel elements. Learning to simplify these circuits is crucial for analysis.

sections.title: Identifying Configurations
sections.content: Look for components that share the same nodes. Group series and parallel elements separately before combining.

sections.title: Step-by-Step Simplification
sections.content: 1. Identify obvious series/parallel groups, 2. Calculate equivalent resistance of each group, 3. Redraw the simplified circuit, 4. Repeat until single equivalent resistance

sections.title: Bridge Circuits
sections.content: More complex configurations like Wheatstone bridges require additional analysis techniques like Kirchhoff's laws.

problems.title: Combined Circuit
problems.description: A 100Ω resistor in series with two 200Ω resistors in parallel. Calculate total resistance.
steps: Now add series resistor: R_total = R_series + R_parallel = 100 + 100 = 200Ω

chapters.title: Circuit Analysis Techniques
chapters.description: Advanced methods for analyzing complex circuits

lessons.title: Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL)
objectives: State and understand Kirchhoff's Current Law

content.introduction: Kirchhoff's Current Law (KCL) states that the algebraic sum of all currents entering and leaving a node is zero. It's essential for analyzing complex circuits.

sections.title: KCL Fundamentals
sections.content: Sum of currents entering = Sum of currents leaving. Alternatively, ΣI_in - ΣI_out = 0 or ΣI = 0 with sign convention.

sections.title: Sign Convention
sections.content: Currents entering a node are positive, currents leaving are negative (or vice versa). Consistency is key.

sections.title: Practical Applications
sections.content: KCL is used in node voltage analysis, current divider circuits, and analyzing parallel networks.

formulas.description: KCL: Sum of currents at a node equals zero
Alternative form: currents in equals currents out

problems.title: KCL at a Node
problems.description: At a circuit node, currents of 2A, 3A, and 1A are entering. If 4A is leaving through one branch, how much current is leaving through the other branch?

lessons.title: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL)
objectives: State and understand Kirchhoff's Voltage Law
Use mesh analysis for complex circuits
Combine KVL and KCL for complete analysis

content.introduction: Kirchhoff's Voltage Law (KVL) states that the algebraic sum of all voltages around any closed loop is zero. It's fundamental to loop and mesh analysis.

sections.title: KVL Fundamentals
sections.content: The sum of voltage rises equals the sum of voltage drops around any closed loop. ΣV_rise = ΣV_drop or ΣV = 0.

sections.title: Sign Convention
sections.content: Moving from negative to positive through a source is a voltage rise. Moving through a resistor in the direction of current is a voltage drop.

sections.title: Mesh Analysis
sections.content: Assign mesh currents to each independent loop, apply KVL to each mesh, solve the resulting system of equations.

formulas.description: KVL: Sum of voltages around a loop equals zero
Alternative form: voltage rises equal voltage drops

problems.title: KVL in a Simple Loop
problems.description: A 12V battery is connected to two resistors of 100Ω and 200Ω in series. Apply KVL to find the current.

chapters.title: Power Systems
chapters.description: Generation, transmission, and distribution of electrical power

lessons.title: Power Generation Fundamentals
objectives: Explain the working principle of generators
Compare renewable and non-renewable energy sources

content.introduction: Electrical power generation converts other forms of energy into electrical energy through various methods including thermal, hydro, nuclear, and renewable sources.

sections.title: AC Power Generation
sections.content: Alternators generate AC power through electromagnetic induction. The frequency is determined by rotational speed and number of poles.

sections.title: Power Plant Types
sections.content: Thermal plants burn fossil fuels, nuclear plants use fission, hydro plants use falling water, and renewable plants use wind, solar, or tidal energy.

sections.title: Grid Connection
sections.content: Generated power is synchronized to the grid at specific voltage and frequency levels before transmission.

formulas.description: Frequency of AC generator: poles × RPM ÷ 120

content.introduction: Diodes are semiconductor devices that allow current to flow in only one direction. They are fundamental components in electronic circuits.

sections.title: PN Junction
sections.content: A diode is formed by joining P-type and N-type semiconductors, creating a depletion region at the junction.

sections.title: Forward Bias
sections.content: When anode is positive relative to cathode, the depletion region narrows and current flows. Typical forward voltage drop is 0.7V for silicon.

sections.title: Reverse Bias
sections.content: When cathode is positive relative to anode, the depletion region widens and only a small leakage current flows until breakdown.

chapters.title: Digital Electronics
chapters.description: Binary logic, digital circuits, and microprocessors

lessons.title: Number Systems and Codes
objectives: Convert between decimal, binary, and hexadecimal
Apply number system knowledge to digital circuits

content.introduction: Digital electronics uses binary number system. Understanding number systems is essential for digital circuit design and programming.

sections.title: Binary System
sections.content: Binary uses only 0 and 1. Each position represents a power of 2. Computers use binary because it's easy to represent with two voltage levels.

sections.title: Hexadecimal
sections.content: Base-16 system using digits 0-9 and letters A-F. Each hex digit represents 4 binary bits, making it a convenient shorthand for binary.

sections.title: Binary Arithmetic
sections.content: Binary addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division follow similar rules to decimal but with simpler tables.

problems.title: Binary to Decimal Conversion
problems.description: Convert the binary number 1011₂ to decimal.

lessons.title: DC Motors
objectives: Understand DC motor construction and operation
Identify different types of DC motors

content.introduction: DC motors convert electrical energy to mechanical energy through electromagnetic principles. They're widely used in applications requiring variable speed control.

sections.title: Construction
sections.content: DC motors have a stator (field windings or permanent magnets) and a rotor (armature) with commutator and brushes.

sections.title: Operation Principle
sections.content: When current flows through armature conductors in a magnetic field, force (F = BIL) produces torque. The commutator reverses current direction each half turn.

sections.title: Types of DC Motors
sections.content: Series motors have high starting torque, shunt motors have constant speed, compound motors combine both characteristics.

chapters.title: Control Systems
chapters.description: Feedback systems, PID controllers, and automation

lessons.title: Introduction to Control Systems
objectives: Understand block diagrams and transfer functions

content.introduction: Control systems manage the behavior of other systems. They're essential in industrial automation, robotics, and many other applications.

sections.title: Open-Loop Systems
sections.content: Open-loop systems operate without feedback. The control action is independent of the process output. Examples include washing machines and traffic lights.

sections.title: Closed-Loop Systems
sections.content: Closed-loop (feedback) systems compare the output to a reference and use the error to adjust the control action. This provides better accuracy and disturbance rejection.

sections.title: Transfer Functions
sections.content: Transfer functions represent the relationship between input and output in the Laplace domain. G(s) = Y(s)/X(s)

chapters.title: Renewable Energy
chapters.description: Solar, wind, and sustainable energy systems

lessons.title: Solar Photovoltaic Systems
objectives: Calculate system sizing and energy production

content.introduction: Solar photovoltaic systems convert sunlight directly into electricity using semiconductor materials. They're a clean, renewable energy source.

sections.title: PV Cell Operation
sections.content: When photons strike the semiconductor junction, electrons are freed and create a voltage potential. Multiple cells form modules, and modules form arrays.

sections.title: System Components
sections.content: PV systems include panels, charge controllers, batteries (for off-grid), inverters (for grid-tied), and balance of system components.

sections.title: Performance Factors
sections.content: Solar output depends on irradiance, temperature, shading, panel orientation, and system efficiency.

lessons.title: Electrical Safety Fundamentals
objectives: Identify electrical hazards and their effects on the human body

content.introduction: Electrical safety is paramount when working with electricity. Understanding hazards and proper procedures prevents accidents and saves lives.

sections.title: Electrical Hazards
sections.content: Electric shock, arc flash, arc blast, and fire are the main electrical hazards. Effects range from minor sensation to cardiac arrest and burns.

sections.title: Safety Standards
sections.content: NFPA 70E, OSHA, and IEC standards provide guidelines for electrical safety. Compliance is mandatory in most jurisdictions.

sections.title: Personal Protective Equipment
sections.content: PPE includes insulated gloves, arc-rated clothing, safety glasses, hard hats, and dielectric footwear rated for the voltage level.
